dialogs.original: Verona, for a while I take my leave,    To see my friends in Padua,   but of all    My best belovèd and approvèd friend,    Hortensio.   And I trow this is his house.    Here, sirrah Grumio. Knock, I say.
dialogs.translated: Farewell for now, Verona. I have come to see my friends in Padua, but especially my best and most beloved friend Hortensio. And I believe this is his house. Here, Grumio. Knock, I say.

dialogs.original: Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Is there any man has rebused your Worship?
dialogs.translated: Knock, sir? Whom should I knock? Has any man rebused your Worship?

dialogs.original: Villain, I say, knock me here soundly.
dialogs.translated: Villain, I say, knock for me here.

dialogs.original: Knock you here, sir? Why, sir, what am I, sir, that I should knock you here, sir?
dialogs.translated: Knock you here, sir? Why, sir, I don't think it's appropriate for me to knock you here, sir.

dialogs.original: Villain, I say, knock me at this gateAnd rap me well, or Ill knock your knaves pate.
dialogs.translated: Villain, I say, knock for me on this door, and pound it well, or I'll knock your fool's head!

dialogs.original: My master is grown quarrelsome. I should knock you first,And then I know after who comes by the worst.
dialogs.translated: My master is getting angry. If I knock him first, then I know who's going to end up sorry for it.

dialogs.original: Will it not be?Faith, sirrah, an youll not knock, Ill ring it.Ill try how you can  sol, fa,  and sing it.
dialogs.translated: Why is this so hard? Well, man, if you won't knock, I'll ringwring your ears and make you sing!

dialogs.original: Help, mistress, help! My master is mad.
dialogs.translated: Help, help! My master's gone crazy.

dialogs.original: Now knock when I bid you, sirrah villain.
dialogs.translated: Now knock when I tell you to, you idiot peasant.

dialogs.original: How now, whats the matter? My old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio? How do you all at Verona?
dialogs.translated: What's going on, what's the matter? Is this my old friend Grumio and my good friend Petruchio? How are all your family in Verona?

dialogs.original: Signior Hortensio, come you to part the fray?  Con tutto il cuore, ben trovato,  may I say.
dialogs.translated: Sir Hortensio, have you come to break up the fig? Let me say con tutto il cuore, ben trovato.

dialogs.original: Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio  Petruchio.Rise, Grumio, rise. We will compound this quarrel.
dialogs.translated: Alla nostra casa ben venuto, molto honorato signor mio Petruchio.Get up, Grumio, get up. We will settle this argument.

dialogs.original: Nay, tis no matter, sir, what he 'leges in Latin. If this be not a lawful case for me to leave his service   look you, sir: he bid me knock him and rap him soundly, sir.   Well, was it fit for a servant to use his master so, being perhaps, for aught I see, two-and-thirty, a pip out?    Whom, would to God, I had well knocked at first,    Then had not Grumio come by the worst.
dialogs.translated: It doesn't matter what he's accused me of in Latin. If this isn't legal justification for me to leave his service, I don't know what is. Listen to this, sir: he tells me to knock him and pound him well, sir. Well, was it proper for a servant to treat his master like thatespecially if he might be a little more drunk than drunk? Maybe I ought to have hit him first, and then I'd feel better.

dialogs.original: A senseless villain, good Hortensio. I bade the rascal knock upon your gateAnd could not get him for my heart to do it.
dialogs.translated: He's a senseless villain, good Hortensio. I told the rascal to knock on your door and couldn't for the life of me get him to do it.

dialogs.original: Knock at the gate? O heavens! Spake you not these wordsplain: Sirrah, knock me here, rap me here, knock me well, and knock me soundly? And come you now with knocking at the gate?
dialogs.translated: Knock on the door? Oh God! Didn't you clearly say the words "Man, knock me here, pound here, and knock me well?" And now you're claiming it was "knocking on the door?"

dialogs.original: Sirrah, begone or talk not, I advise you.
dialogs.translated: Be quiet or go away, I warn you.

dialogs.original: Petruchio, patience. I am Grumios pledge.    Why, this' a heavy chance twixt him and you,    Your ancient, trusty, pleasant servant Grumio.    And tell me now, sweet friend, what happy gale    Blows you to Padua here from old Verona?
dialogs.translated: Calm down, Petruchio. I'll vouch for Grumio. Why, this is sad to see you two fightingyou and Grumio, your trusty, cheerful servant of many years. But tell me now, sweet friend, what lucky wind blew you from old Verona here to Padua.

dialogs.original: Such wind as scatters young men through the world    To seek their fortunes farther than at home,    Where small experience grows.   But in a few,    Signior Hortensio, thus it stands with me:    Antonio, my father, is deceased,    And I have thrust myself into this maze,    Happily to wive and thrive as best I may.    Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home,    And so am come abroad to see the world.
dialogs.translated: The wind that scatters young men throughout the world to seek their fortunes away from home, where there are few new experiences to be had. But to be brief, Sir Hortensio, this is how it stands: Antonio, my father, is dead, and I have now thrown myself into the wide world to try and marry and thrive as best I can. I have money in my purse and property at home, so I've set off to see the world.

dialogs.original: Petruchio, shall I then come roundly to thee    And wish thee to a shrewd, ill-favored wife?    Thoudst thank me but a little for my counsel;    And yet Ill promise thee she shall be rich,    And very rich.   But thou'rt too much my friend,    And Ill not wish thee to her.
dialogs.translated: Petruchio, should I speak plainly then and offer you a shrewish, unpleasant wife? I don't think you'd thank me for my suggestion, but I promise you she's rich, yes, very rich. But you are my friend, so I won't wish her on you.

dialogs.original: Signior Hortensio, twixt such friends as we    Few words suffice.   And therefore, if thou know    One rich enough to be Petruchios wife,    As wealth is burden of my wooing dance,    Be she as foul as was Florentius' love,    As old as Sibyl and as curst and shrewd    As Socrates' Xanthippe, or a worse,    She moves me not, or not removes at least    Affections edge in me, were she as rough    As are the swelling Adriatic seas.    I come to wive it wealthily in Padua;    If wealthily, then happily in Padua.
dialogs.translated: Sir Hortensio, for good friends like us only a few words are needed. So if you know a woman rich enough to be Petruchio's wifeand wealth is the biggest factor for meit doesn't matter if she's as ugly as Florentius' love, as old as the Sybil, or as shrewish as Socrates' Xanthippe. None of that would bother me, or make me less keen to marry her, even if she were as rough as the Adriatic Sea. I've come to find a wealthy wife in Padua, and if she's wealthy, then I'll have found a good wife.

dialogs.original: [To HORTENSIO]   Nay, look you, sir, he tells you flatlywhat his mind is.   Why, give him gold enough and marry him to a puppet or an aglet-baby, or an old trot with ne'er a tooth in her head, though she have as many diseases as two-and-fifty horses.   Why, nothing comes amiss, so money comes withal.
dialogs.translated: [To HORTENSIO] Look at that, sir, he is very straightforward with his intentions. Why, if you give him enough gold he'll marry a puppet, a doll, or an old prostitute with a dozen diseases and not a tooth in her head. Why, nothing can bother him, as long as money comes with it.

dialogs.original: Petruchio, since we are stepped thus far in,    I will continue that I broached in jest.    I can, Petruchio, help thee to a wife    With wealth enough, and young and beauteous,    Brought up as best becomes a gentlewoman.    Her only fault, and that is faults enough,    Is that she is intolerable curst,    And shrewd and froward,   so beyond all measure    That, were my state far worser than it is,    I would not wed her for a mine of gold.
dialogs.translated: Petruchio, since the conversation has gone this far already, I'll continue with what I meant only as a joke. I can help you find a wife, Petruchio, who's rich, young, beautiful, and brought up as a noble gentlewoman. Her only flaw, and it's certainly a big one, is that she is an unbearable shrew, disagreeable and willful, and so much so that even if I was broke I wouldn't marry her for a goldmine.

dialogs.original: Hortensio, peace. Thou knowst not golds effect.    Tell me her fathers name, and tis enough;    For I will board her, though she chide as loud    As thunder when the clouds in autumn crack.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, Hortensio. You don't know the power of money. Tell me her father's name, and that will be enough. I will pursue her even if her scolding is as loud as thunder in an autumn storm.

dialogs.original: Her father is Baptista Minola,    An affable and courteous gentleman.    Her name is Katherina Minola,    Renowned in Padua for her scolding tongue.
dialogs.translated: Her father is Baptista Minola, an agreeable and polite gentleman. Her name is Katherina Minola, famous in Padua for her scolding tongue.

dialogs.original: I know her father, though I know not her,    And he knew my deceasèd father well.    I will not sleep, Hortensio, till I see her,    And therefore let me be thus bold with you    To give you over at this first encounter,    Unless you will accompany me thither.
dialogs.translated: I don't know her, but I know her father, and he knew my father well when he was alive. I won't sleep until I see her, Hortensio, so I hope you'll pardon me for cutting off this first meeting of oursunless you want to come with me.

dialogs.original: [To HORTENSIO]   I pray you, sir, let him go while the humor lasts.   O' my word, an she knew him as well as I do, she would think scolding would do little good upon him.   She may perhaps call him half a score knaves or so.Why, thats nothing;   an he begin once, hell rail in his rope tricks.   Ill tell you what sir: an she stand him but a little, he will throw a figure in her face andso disfigure her with it that she shall have no more eyes to see withal than a cat.   You know him not, sir.
dialogs.translated: [To HORTENSIO] Please, sir, let him go while this mood lasts. I swear, if she knew him as well as I do, she'd know how little scolding affects him. At best, she might come up with ten or so horrible names to call him. Why, that's nothing. Once he gets started, he'll rant and rave and throw his rope tricks around, and if she tries to stand up to him, he'll throw a figure of speech in her face that'll disfigure her so she'll have no more eyes to see with than a cat does. You don't know him, sir.

dialogs.original: Tarry, Petruchio, I must go with thee,    For in Baptistas keep my treasure is.    He hath the jewel of my life in hold,    His youngest daughter, beautiful Bianca,    And her withholds from me and other more,    Suitors to her and rivals in my love,    Supposing it a thing impossible,    For those defects I have before rehearsed,    That ever Katherina will be wooed.    Therefore this order hath Baptista ta'en,    That none shall have access unto Bianca    Till Katherine the curst have got a husband.
dialogs.translated: Wait, Petruchio. I must go with you, for my own treasure is in Baptista's keeping too. He has my precious jewel hidden away in his fortress: his youngest daughter, the beautiful Bianca. He keeps her away from me and her other suitors, my rivals for her love, as he assumes it will be impossiblebecause of those character defects I already describedfor Katherina to ever find a husband. Baptista has therefore set down this rule: no one will have access to Bianca until Katherine the shrew gets a husband.

dialogs.original: Katherine the curst!A title for a maid of all titles the worst.
dialogs.translated: "Katherine the shrew!" Of all the titles you could give a girl, that's the worst.

dialogs.original: Now shall my friend Petruchio do me grace,    And offer me disguised in sober robes    To old Baptista as a schoolmaster    Well seen in music, to instruct Bianca,    That so I may, by this device at least,    Have leave and leisure to make love to her    And, unsuspected, court her by herself.
dialogs.translated: Now my friend Petruchio will do me a favor, and present medisguised in somber robesto Baptista as a teacher, well-versed in music, to instruct Bianca. With this disguise, I'll at least have time and permission to be with Bianca alone, and then I can court her once more.

dialogs.original: Heres no knavery! See, to beguile the old folks, how the young folks lay their heads together!
dialogs.translated: What a nice trick! See how the young folks put their heads together to deceive the old.

dialogs.original: Master, master, look about you. Who goes there, ha?
dialogs.translated: Master, master, look behind you. Who's that, huh?

dialogs.original: Peace, Grumio. It is the rival of my love.Petruchio, stand by a while.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, Grumio. It is my rival for Biana's love. Petruchio, let's watch a while.

dialogs.original: [aside]  A proper stripling, and an amorous.
dialogs.translated: [To himself, indicating GREMIO] What a handsome young man! A real heartbreaker.

dialogs.original: [To LUCENTIO]   O, very well, I have perused the note.    Hark you, sir: Ill have them very fairly bound,    All books of love.   See that at any hand,    And see you read no other lectures to her.    You understand me. Over and beside    Signior Baptistas liberality,    Ill mend it with a largess.   Take your paper too.    And let me have them very well perfumd    For she is sweeter than perfume itself    To whom they go to.   What will you read to her?
dialogs.translated: [To LUCENTIO] Oh, very well, I've read the list of books for Bianca. Now listen, sir: I want them very handsomely bound, and I want them to be books of love. No matter what, don't teach her any other lessons. Do you understand me? Above and beyond what Sir Baptista pays you, I'll add on a hefty bonus. Take your book list too. And have all the books well perfumed too, for the lady they're going to is sweeter than perfume itself. What will you teach her?

dialogs.original: [as CAMBIO]   Whate'er I read to her, Ill plead for you    As for my patron, stand you so assured,    As firmly as yourself were still in place,  Yea, and perhaps with more successful wordsThan you, unless you were a scholar, sir.
dialogs.translated: [As CAMBIO] Whatever I teach her, I'll plead your case. You can be sure of thatI'll argue for you as strongly as if you were there yourself. And maybe I'll be more successful than you would be too, sir, unless you were a scholar.

dialogs.original: O this learning, what a thing it is!
dialogs.translated: Oh, this learning, what an excellent thing it is!

dialogs.original: [aside]  O this woodcock, what an ass it is!
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Oh, this moron, what an ass it is!

dialogs.original: [aside]  Peace, sirrah.
dialogs.translated: [So only GRUMIO can hear] Quiet, boy.

dialogs.original: [aside]  Grumio, mum! God save you, Signior Gremio.
dialogs.translated: [So only GRUMIO can hear] Grumio, hush!

dialogs.original: And you are well met, Signior Hortensio.    Trow you whither I am going? To Baptista Minola.    I promised to enquire carefully    About a schoolmaster for the fair Bianca,    And by good fortune I have lighted well    On this young man,   for learning and behavior    Fit for her turn, well read in poetry    And other booksgood ones, I warrant ye.
dialogs.translated: Good to see you, Sir Hortensio. Do you know where I'm going? To see Baptista Minola. I promised that I would find a teacher for the fair Bianca, and my good luck has led me to this young man. His manners and learning are well-suited for her needs, and he's well-read in poetry and other booksgood books, I assure you.

dialogs.original: 'Tis well. And I have met a gentleman    Hath promised me to help me to another,    A fine musician to instruct our mistress.    So shall I no whit be behind in duty    To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.
dialogs.translated: That's good. And I have met a gentleman who has promised to help find a fine musician to teach our lady. So I won't fall even a step behind in my duty to fair Bianca, my beloved.

dialogs.original: Beloved of me, and that my deeds shall prove.
dialogs.translated: My belovedas my deeds will prove.

dialogs.original: [aside]  And that his bags shall prove.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] And as his moneybags will prove.

dialogs.original: Gremio, tis now no time to vent our love.    Listen to me, and if you speak me fair,    Ill tell you news indifferent good for either.    [presenting  PETRUCHIO  ]    Here is a gentleman whom by chance I met,    Upon agreement from us to his liking,    Will undertake to woo curst Katherine,    Yea, and to marry her, if her dowry please.
dialogs.translated: Gremio, now is not the time to express our love. If you're willing to be polite and listen to me, then I'll give you some news that's equally good for both of us.

dialogs.original: So said, so done, is well.Hortensio, have you told him all her faults?
dialogs.translated: If he'll do as he says, then that's good. But Hortensio, have you told him about all her flaws?

dialogs.original: I know she is an irksome brawling scold.If that be all, masters, I hear no harm.
dialogs.translated: I know she is an annoying, argumentative scolder. If that's all, masters, then I see no problem.

dialogs.original: No? Sayst me so, friend? What countryman?
dialogs.translated: No? Is that what you're telling me, friend? Where are you from?

dialogs.original: Born in Verona, old Antonios son.My father dead, my fortune lives for me.And I do hope good days and long to see.
dialogs.translated: I was born in Verona. I'm old Antonio's son. My father is dead, and his fortune is mine now. I hope to see many long, good days.

dialogs.original: O sir, such a life with such a wife were strange!    But if you have a stomach, to t, i' Gods name:    You shall have me assisting you in all.  But will you woo this wildcat?
dialogs.translated: Oh sir, such a life with such a wife will be strange! But if you have the stomach for it, then godspeedand you'll have my help in everything you need. But will you really woo this wildcat?

dialogs.original: Will I live?
dialogs.translated: As long as I'm alive.

dialogs.original: Will he woo her? Ay, or Ill hang her.
dialogs.translated: Will he woo her? Yes, or I'll hang her.

dialogs.original: Why came I hither but to that intent?    Think you a little din can daunt mine ears?    Have I not in my time heard lions roar?    Have I not heard the sea, puffed up with winds,    Rage like an angry boar chafèd with sweat?    Have I not heard great ordnance in the field,    And heavens artillery thunder in the skies?    Have I not in a pitchèd battle heard    Loud 'larums, neighing steeds, and trumpets' clang?    And do you tell me of a womans tongue    That gives not half so great a blow to hear    As will a chestnut in a farmers fire?    Tush, tush! Fear boys with bugs.
dialogs.translated: Why did I come here if not for that? Do you think a little noise can frighten me? Haven't I heard lions roar? Haven't I heard the windy sea rage like an angry boar? Haven't I heard cannons on the battlefield, and thunderheaven's artilleryin the sky? Haven't I been at war and heard loud calls to arms, neighing horses, and trumpets blasting? And now you warn me about some woman's tongue, which isn't even half as loud as a chestnut popping in a farmer's fire? For shame! Save your bogeymen to frighten children.

dialogs.original: For he fears none.
dialogs.translated: For he fears nothing.

dialogs.original: Hortensio, hark.This gentleman is happily arrived,My mind presumes, for his own good and ours.
dialogs.translated: Hortensio, listen. This gentleman has arrived at a fortunate time, I thinkfor both our good and his.

dialogs.original: I promised we would be contributorsAnd bear his charge of wooing, whatsoe'er.
dialogs.translated: I promised that we would all contribute and pay the expenses for his courtship, whatever they turn out to be.

dialogs.original: And so we will, provided that he win her.
dialogs.translated: And so we will, as long as he wins Katherine.

dialogs.original: I would I were as sure of a good dinner.
dialogs.translated: I wish I could be as sure of a good dinner.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,Tell me, I beseech you, which is the readiest wayTo the house of Signior Baptista Minola?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] God bless you, gentlemen. If I may be so bold, please tell me, which is the best way to the house of Sir Baptista Minola?

dialogs.original: He that has the two fair daughtersis t he you mean?
dialogs.translated: The man with the two pretty daughtersis that who you mean?

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Even he, Biondello.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] The very man, Biondello.

dialogs.original: Hark you, sir, you mean not her to
dialogs.translated: Listen, sir, you're not looking for the daughter

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Perhaps him and her, sir. What have you to do?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Maybe I mean the father and the daughter, sir. What is it to you?

dialogs.original: Not her that chides, sir, at any hand, I pray.
dialogs.translated: Not the daughter who scolds, anyway, I hope.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  I love no chiders, sir. Biondello, lets away.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] I have no love for scolders, sir. Biondello, let's go.

dialogs.original: [aside]  Well begun, Tranio.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Well done, Tranio.

dialogs.original: Sir, a word ere you go. Are you a suitor to the maid you talk of, yea or no?
dialogs.translated: [To TRANIO] Sir, a word before you go. Are you a suitor to the girl you asked aboutyes or no?

dialogs.original: An if I be, sir, is it any offense?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] And if I am, sir, is it a problem?

dialogs.original: No, if without more words you will get you hence.
dialogs.translated: Not if you get out of here without saying another word.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  Why, sir, I pray, are not the streets as free For me as for you?
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Why, sir, don't I have just as much a right to be out on the streets as you do?

dialogs.original: But so is not she.
dialogs.translated: But she doesn't.

dialogs.original: For what reason, I beseech you?
dialogs.translated: For what reason, I ask you?

dialogs.original: For this reason, if youll know:That shes the choice love of Signior Gremio.
dialogs.translated: For this reason, if you want to know: because she's the chosen beloved of Sir Gremio.

dialogs.original: That shes the chosen of Signior Hortensio.
dialogs.translated: Because she's the chosen beloved of Sir Hortensio.

dialogs.original: Softly, my masters. If you be gentlemen,    Do me this right: hear me with patience.    Baptista is a noble gentleman,    To whom my father is not all unknown,    And were his daughter fairer than she is,    She may more suitors have,   and me for one.    Fair Ledas daughter had a thousand wooers;    Then well one more may fair Bianca have.    And so she shall. Lucentio shall make one,    Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.
dialogs.translated: Calm down, sirs. If you're gentleman, then be polite and hear me out. Baptista is a noble gentlemanone who knows my fatherand even if his daughter was more beautiful than she already is, she would still be entitled to more than one suitorand I will be one of them. Helen of Troy had a thousand suitors, so let fair Bianca have one more. And so she does. Lucentio will woo her, even if Paris himself should come to try and win her.

dialogs.original: What! This gentleman will out-talk us all.
dialogs.translated: What! This gentleman will out-talk us all.

dialogs.original: [as CAMBIO]  Sir, give him head; I know hell prove a jade.
dialogs.translated: [As CAMBIO] Well, let him sprint ahead for now. He's not likely to finish the race.

dialogs.original: Hortensio, to what end are all these words?
dialogs.translated: Hortensio, what's all this talk about?

dialogs.original: [To TRANIO]  Sir, let me be so bold as ask you,Did you yet ever see Baptistas daughter?
dialogs.translated: [To TRANIO] Sir, if I may be so bold as to ask you, have you even seen Baptista's daughter yet?

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]  No, sir, but hear I do that he hath two, The one as famous for a scolding tongueAs is the other for beauteous modesty.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] No, sir, but I hear that he has two, the one as famous for her scolding tongue as the other is for her beauty and modesty.

dialogs.original: Sir, sir, the firsts for me; let her go by.
dialogs.translated: Sir, sir, the first one's mine, so let her go by.

dialogs.original: Yea, leave that labor to great Hercules,And let it be more than Alcides' twelve.
dialogs.translated: Yes, leave that labor to great Herculesit's worse than all the other Twelve Labors put together.

dialogs.original: [To TRANIO]   Sir, understand you this of me, in sooth:    The youngest daughter, whom you hearken for,    Her father keeps from all access of suitors    And will not promise her to any man    Until the elder sister first be wed.    The younger then is free, and not before.
dialogs.translated: [To TRANIO] Sir, let me make sure you understand this: the youngest daughter, the one you long for, is kept locked away from all suitors by her father. He won't promise her to any man until the elder sister is married first. Then, and only then, will the younger be free.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   If it be so, sir, that you are the man    Must stead us all, and me amongst the rest,    And if you break the ice and do this feat,    Achieve the elder, set the younger free    For our access,   whose hap shall be to have her    Will not so graceless be to be ingrate.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] If that's true, sir, and you are the man who will help us allmyself includedand you do break the ice and perform the incredible feat of winning the elder sister, thereby setting the younger free for us to woothen I'm sure whoever happens to win her won't be such a brute as to be ungrateful to you.

dialogs.original: Sir, you say well, and well you do conceive.    And since you do profess to be a suitor,    You must, as we do, gratify this gentleman,    To whom we all rest generally beholding.
dialogs.translated: Sir, you speak well, and you understand well. And since you declare yourself a suitor, you must do as we already have, and pay this gentleman to whom we all owe so much.

dialogs.original: [as LUCENTIO]   Sir, I shall not be slack;   in sign whereof,    Please ye we may contrive this afternoon    And quaff carouses to our mistress' health    And do as adversaries do in law,    Strive mightily, but eat and drink as friends.
dialogs.translated: [As LUCENTIO] Sir, I won't be stingy. On that note, let's spend this afternoon drinking toasts to our beloved's health. We'll be like opposing lawyers in a case, who fight viciously in court, but outside of it eat and drink as friends.

dialogs.original: O excellent motion! Fellows, lets be gone.
dialogs.translated: An excellent suggestion! Fellows, let's go.

dialogs.original: The motions good indeed and be it so.Petruchio, I shall be your  ben venuto.
dialogs.translated: It's a good suggestion, so let's do it.Petruchio, let me buy you a drink as your host.
